metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Scaling up Vue
Using *.vue files for our Vue project makes sense because:
content.html: Using *.vue files for our Vue project makes sense because:

content.text: Why?
As we saw on the previous page about templates and components in Vue, there is now a need for different way to work because we want to:
content.html: As we saw on the previous page about templates and components in Vue, there is now a need for different way to work because we want to:

content.text: And to make all this possible we must switch to *.vue files.
content.html: And to make all this possible we must switch to *.vue files.

content.text: How?

SFCs (Single File Components), or *.vue files, are easier to work with but cannot run directly in the browser, so we need to set up our computer to compile our *.vue files to *.html, *.css and *.js files so that the browser can run our Vue application.
content.html: SFCs (Single File Components), or *.vue files, are easier to work with but cannot run directly in the browser, so we need to set up our computer to compile our *.vue files to *.html, *.css and *.js files so that the browser can run our Vue application.

content.text: To build our web page based on SFCs we use a program called Vite as the build tool, and we write our code in the VS Code editor with the Volar extension for Vue 3 language features.
content.html: To build our web page based on SFCs we use a program called Vite as the build tool, and we write our code in the VS Code editor with the Volar extension for Vue 3 language features.

content.text: Setup
Follow the three steps below to install what you need to run Vue SFC applications on your computer.
content.html: Follow the three steps below to install what you need to run Vue SFC applications on your computer.

content.text: The "VS Code" Editor
content.html: The "VS Code" Editor

content.text: There are many different editors that can be used for Vue projects. We use the VS Code editor. Download VS Code and install it.
content.html: There are many different editors that can be used for Vue projects. We use the VS Code editor. Download VS Code and install it.

content.text: The VS Code "Volar" Extension
content.html: The VS Code "Volar" Extension

content.text: To get highlighting and auto-completion with *.vue files in the editor, open VS Code, go to "Extensions" on the left hand side. Search for "Volar" and install the extension with the most downloads and the description "Language support for Vue 3".
content.html: To get highlighting and auto-completion with *.vue files in the editor, open VS Code, go to "Extensions" on the left hand side. Search for "Volar" and install the extension with the most downloads and the description "Language support for Vue 3".

content.text: Node.js
content.html: Node.js

content.text: Download and install the latest version of Node.js , as the Vue build tool "Vite" runs on top of this.
content.html: Download and install the latest version of Node.js, as the Vue build tool "Vite" runs on top of this.

content.text: Node.js is an open-source server-side JavaScript runtime environment.
content.html: Node.js is an open-source server-side JavaScript runtime environment.

content.text: Create The Default Example Project
Follow the steps below to create the default Vue example project on your computer.
content.html: Follow the steps below to create the default Vue example project on your computer.

content.text: Create a folder for your Vue projects on your computer.
content.html: Create a folder for your Vue projects on your computer.

content.text: In VS Code, open a terminal by choosing Terminal -> New Terminal from the menu:
content.html: In VS Code, open a terminal by choosing Terminal -> New Terminal from the menu:

content.text: Use the terminal to navigate to the Vue folder you just created by using commands like cd <folder-name> , cd .. , ls (Mac/Linux) and dir (Windows). If you are not familiar with writing commands in the terminal, see our introduction to Command Line Interface (CLI) here .
content.html: Use the terminal to navigate to the Vue folder you just created by using commands like cd <folder-name>, cd .., ls (Mac/Linux) and dir (Windows). If you are not familiar with writing commands in the terminal, see our introduction to Command Line Interface (CLI) here.

content.text: After you have navigated to your Vue folder in the terminal, write:
content.html: After you have navigated to your Vue folder in the terminal, write:

content.text: Create your first project, with project name "firstsfc":
content.html: Create your first project, with project name "firstsfc":

content.text: Answer "No" to all options:
content.html: Answer "No" to all options:

content.text: Now you should be presented with this in your terminal:
content.html: Now you should be presented with this in your terminal:

content.text: We will now run the commands as suggested above.
content.html: We will now run the commands as suggested above.

content.text: Run this command to change directory to your new project inside the 'firstsfc' folder:
content.html: Run this command to change directory to your new project inside the 'firstsfc' folder:

content.text: Install all required dependencies so that the Vue project works:
content.html: Install all required dependencies so that the Vue project works:

content.text: Start the development server:
content.html: Start the development server:

content.code_html: npm run dev

content.text: The terminal window should now look like this:
content.html: The terminal window should now look like this:

content.text: And your browser should open the example project automatically:
content.html: And your browser should open the example project automatically:

content.text: If you cannot find the example project in the browser, use the link from the terminal. The link you find in your terminal window might have a different address than the address in the screenshot above.
content.html: If you cannot find the example project in the browser, use the link from the terminal. The link you find in your terminal window might have a different address than the address in the screenshot above.

content.text: Now the example project is running on your machine in development mode by the Vite build tool.
content.html: Now the example project is running on your machine in development mode by the Vite build tool.

content.text: The Project Files
The example project that has automatically been created contains many files, and we will take a quick look at a few of them.
content.html: The example project that has automatically been created contains many files, and we will take a quick look at a few of them.

content.text: main.js
Go to your Vue project in the VS Code editor, find the "main.js" file in the "src" folder:
content.html: Go to your Vue project in the VS Code editor, find the "main.js" file in the "src" folder:

content.text: "main.js" tells Vite how to build the Vue project based on the "App.vue" file. This is similar to how we previously gave a CDN link with the script tag to tell the browser how to run our Vue code, and how we mounted the Vue instance to the <div id="app"> tag.
content.html: "main.js" tells Vite how to build the Vue project based on the "App.vue" file. This is similar to how we previously gave a CDN link with the script tag to tell the browser how to run our Vue code, and how we mounted the Vue instance to the <div id="app"> tag.

content.text: App.vue
In the same example project folder, find the "App.vue" file and open it. Like all other *.vue files, "App.vue" contains three parts: a <script> part, a <template> part and a <style> part.
content.html: In the same example project folder, find the "App.vue" file and open it. Like all other *.vue files, "App.vue" contains three parts: a <script> part, a <template> part and a <style> part.

content.code_html:
<script setup>
import HelloWorld from './components/HelloWorld.vue'
import TheWelcome from './components/TheWelcome.vue'
</script>

<template>
  <header>
    <img alt="Vue logo" class="logo" src="./assets/logo.svg" width="125" height="125" />

    <div class="wrapper">
      <HelloWorld msg="You did it!" />
    </div>
  </header>

  <main>
    <TheWelcome />
  </main>
</template>

<style scoped>
header {
  line-height: 1.5;
}

.logo {
  display: block;
  margin: 0 auto 2rem;
}

@media (min-width: 1024px) {
  header {
    display: flex;
    place-items: center;
    padding-right: calc(var(--section-gap) / 2);
  }

  .logo {
    margin: 0 2rem 0 0;
  }

  header .wrapper {
    display: flex;
    place-items: flex-start;
    flex-wrap: wrap;
  }
}
</style>

content.text: As you can see in the script part of "App.vue", other *.vue files are referred to: those are 'components' and are located in the 'components' folder. If you take a look in the 'template' part of the 'App.vue' file, you can see tags that are not normal HTML tags: <HelloWorld> and <TheWelcome> . This is how the components are referred to. Components are like apps within the app. We will learn more about components soon.
content.html: As you can see in the script part of "App.vue", other *.vue files are referred to: those are 'components' and are located in the 'components' folder. If you take a look in the 'template' part of the 'App.vue' file, you can see tags that are not normal HTML tags: <HelloWorld> and <TheWelcome>. This is how the components are referred to. Components are like apps within the app. We will learn more about components soon.
